resources.text: Your task is to create a program that reads input from the user (name, age, etc...) and performs some operations according to this data. It will then finally display its operations in the console and also save it to a text file.
resources.boxed: This program will need to know the current year. Hardcoding it is bad practice, as the code will give wrong results next year. Instead, take a look at the following code sample which shows how to get the current year as an integer variable:
resources.text: This code uses java.time, which was added with Java 8.

The program will need one command line argument. This can either be SAVE or NO_SAVE. If it is SAVE, the program must perform the tasks detailed in the 'save to file' paragraph. If it is NO_SAVE, these tasks must not be performed.
resources.boxed:
If no argument is given, or it's neither SAVE not NO_SAVE, then the System.err channel must be used to indicate the problem, and the program should halt. Use the code sample below to terminate the program.

To compare strings, use the equals method instead of the == operator! The reasons behind this are explained in a later course.
resources.text: At start, after checking the command line argument, the program must ask the user their name, age and profession. Store these in appropriate variables, as they will be used later.
resources.boxed: Try to validate the given data as much as possible. For example, your program should not accept if the user entered nothing for name or profession or a negative age.
resources.advanced:
The given age will be parsed to an integer. To make your program more stable, you can try to implement simple exception handling for the NumberFormatException.

Use the try-catch block to notify the user of the problem instead of crashing the program.
resources.text: At this point the inputs should be validated. Calculate and print the following things to the console:
resources.list:
• The year the user was born.
  • The year the user turned 18. If he has not yet turned 18, print that.
  • All the years the user was alive in (see below for details).
resources.boxed: The years the user was alive should be stored in a list. They should be printed to the console separated by commas in a way that there is a line break after every 6. of them.
resources.text: If the user passed the SAVE command line argument, perform the following things:
resources.list:
• Create a file called 'userdata.txt'
  • Overwrite and don't append if it exists.
  • Write the name, age and profession into the file, in a formatted way.
  • Write the years the user was alive in using the same formatting specified above.
resources.text: Feel free to use the way shown in chapters 'input' and 'output' to bypass file related exception handling.
resources.advanced: If you wish to make your code better, try to handle the file related exceptions instead of "suppressing" them with throws Exception.
resources.boxed: Don't forget to abide the coding conventions. Comment your code! Write methods for the subtasks and use parameters and return values to communicate between them!

solution.text: This solution only uses one class, and a few methods. Exception handling was not mandatory, but it's implemented in this example solution.
solution.code:
package userinput;

import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.PrintWriter;
import java.time.Year;
import java.util.InputMismatchException;
import java.util.Scanner;

public class Main {

    public static void main(String[] args) {
         //check the command line argument
         boolean save = saveEnabled(args);
         
         //ask for user data
         Scanner scanner = new Scanner(System.in);
         System.out.print("Enter your name: ");
         String name = scanner.nextLine();
         System.out.print("Enter your age: ");
         int age = 0;
         try { //exception handling for age
              age = Integer.parseInt(scanner.nextLine());
         } catch(InputMismatchException e) {
              System.err.println("Error: invalid age!");
              System.exit(0);
         }
         System.out.print("What is your profession? ");
         String prof = scanner.nextLine();
         scanner.close();
         
         validateData(name, prof, age); //check inputs
         
         ageCalculations(age); //age related tasks
         
         if(save) { //if saving is active, write to file
              saveToFile(name, prof, age);
         }
    }
    
    /*
    This method checks if saving is enabled using the command line arguments.
    If the argument is valid a boolean is returned that indicates if saving is enabled.
     */
    static boolean saveEnabled(String[] args) {
         if(args.length != 1) { //1 argument is allowed
              System.err.println("Wrong number of args!");
              System.exit(0);
         }
         
         if(args[0].equals("SAVE")) {
              return true;
         } else if(args[0].equals("NO_SAVE")) {
              return false;
         } else { //unknown argument
              System.err.println("Invalid argument: " + args[0]);
              System.exit(0);
              
              /*
              the program won't get to this return statement,
              but the compiler requires it.
               */
              return false;
         }
    }
    
    //this method checks if the user entered valid inputs
    static void validateData(String name, String prof, int age) {
         //the length method counts the characters in a string!
         if(name.length() == 0 || prof.length() == 0) {
              System.err.println("Empty string is not accepted!");
              System.exit(0);
         }
         if(age < 0) {
              System.err.println("Age can't be negative!");
              System.exit(0);
         }
    }
    
    //performs the age related tasks
    static void ageCalculations(int age) {
         //calculate the birth year
         int currentYear = Year.now().getValue();
         int birthYear = currentYear - age;
         System.out.println("\nYou were born in " + birthYear);
         
         //calculate the year of becoming 18
         if(age >= 18) {
              System.out.println("You turned 18 in " + (birthYear+18));
         } else {
              System.out.println("You are not yet 18!");
         }
         
         //print all years in which the user is/was alive
         System.out.println("The years you were alive in are:");
         System.out.println(createYearsString(age));
    }
    
    /*
    Makes a string that contains the years the user was
    alive in.
    This is extracted to a method so it can be reused when
    printing to the file as well.
     */
    static String createYearsString(int age) {
         int currentYear = Year.now().getValue();
         int birthYear = currentYear - age;
         //the string is empty at the beginning
         String printedYears = "";
         int columnCounter = 0; //this is used to format the years
         for(int year = birthYear; year <= currentYear; year++) {
              //add the next year to the string
              printedYears = printedYears + year + ", ";
              columnCounter++;
              if(columnCounter == 6) { //break line at column 6
                   printedYears = printedYears + "\n";
                   columnCounter = 0;
              }
         }
         return printedYears;
    }
    
    //creates a file and writes the data into it
    static void saveToFile(String name, String profession, int age) {
         try { //this solution uses exception handling
              PrintWriter writer = new PrintWriter("userdata.txt", "UTF-8");
              //writer all data into the file
              writer.println("Name: " + name);
              writer.println("Age: " + age);
              writer.println("Profession:" + profession);
              writer.println("Years alive: ");
              writer.println(createYearsString(age));
              writer.close();
         } catch(IOException e) {
              System.err.println("File writing exception!");
         }
    }
}
